title: R44078
content: The FY2016 judiciary appropriations process began with the submission of the budget request on February 2, 2015. Subsequent actions included hearings by House and Senate subcommittees, markups by the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 on December 18, 2015. The budget request was for $7.519 billion in new budget authority for judicial branch activities. The judiciary appropriations process for FY2016 began with a budget request of $7.519 billion in new budget authority. Hearings and markups were held by House and Senate subcommittees, with the House Appropriations Committee recommending $7.48 billion and the full committee recommending $7.47 billion for the judiciary. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-20. The judiciary appropriations process for FY2016 began with a budget request of $7.519 billion. The House and Senate subcommittees recommended $7.42 billion for the judiciary. No further action was taken on the bills before the start of FY2016. Judicial branch activities were funded through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 (P.L. 114-113) provided $7.3 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $73.9 million from FY2015. This funding was $184.1 million less than the requested amount. In FY2015, judiciary funding was $7.261 billion, an increase of $221.9 million from FY2014. A funding gap in FY2014 led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days, which was resolved by a continuing appropriations resolution (P.L. 113-46). The funding gap in FY2014 led to a 16-day government shutdown, resolved by a continuing appropriations resolution (P.L. 113-46). This resolution provided funding through January 15, 2014, followed by a consolidated appropriations bill on January 17 (P.L. 113-76) allocating $7.039 billion for the judiciary in FY2014. The judiciary's budget includes funding for the Supreme Court and lower federal courts, with the largest account being the Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts. The Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services make up 73% of the total FY2016 enacted level. This account covers salaries of judges, retired judges, and other court employees, as well as necessary court expenses. Other significant accounts include Defender Services (13.7%) and Court Security (7.4%). The remaining judiciary budget is allocated to various specific entities within the federal judiciary. The judiciary budget includes funding for various entities such as U.S. Courts, Federal Judicial Center, U.S. Sentencing Commission, and Judicial Retirement Funds. Specialized courts like the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces, U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims, and U.S. Tax Court are funded separately. Non-appropriated funds, mainly from court filing fees, help offset expenses within the judiciary. The judiciary budget includes funding for various entities like U.S. Courts, Federal Judicial Center, U.S. Sentencing Commission, and Judicial Retirement Funds. Non-appropriated funds, primarily from court filing fees, are used to offset expenses within the Salaries and Expenses account of Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services. These funds may be carried forward from one year to the next and are considered "unencumbered" savings from the judiciary's financial plan. The judiciary also has "encumbered" funds appropriated for specific purposes. Judge Julia S. Gibbons discussed the judiciary's cost-containment initiatives, achieving a cost avoidance of nearly $1.5 billion over 10 years. Current efforts focus on shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. The judiciary has made progress in reducing its space footprint, with a goal of a 3% reduction set in 2013. Judge Gibbons reported that as of March 2015, 30% of the goal has been achieved, resulting in $5.8 million in rent cost avoidance. Efforts to improve judicial security have been prompted by past incidents of violence against judges and court personnel. The judiciary has implemented security measures to protect judges and court personnel, including intrusion detection systems in judges' homes and enhanced courtroom safety. The U.S. Marshals Service works with the judiciary to ensure protective policies are in place. A pilot program since FY2009 has USMS responsible for perimeter security at selected courthouses previously under FPS. The pilot program, implemented on January 5, 2009, by the U.S. Marshals Service, assumed security functions at seven courthouses in various locations. The Judicial Conference recommended creating 73 new federal judgeships in March 2015, with similar requests made in previous Congresses. Legislation was introduced but no final action was taken before the 113th Congress adjourned. Since the enactment of an omnibus judgeship bill in 1990, the number of appellate judgeships has remained at 179 while appellate court case filings increased by 28%. District judgeships increased by 5% to 677, with district court case filings increasing by 41%. The FY2016 judiciary budget request is $7.53 billion, with the Supreme Court requesting $88.2 million. The House and Senate committee-reported levels were $88.0 million and $88.4 million respectively, with a total of $88.4 million provided in P.L. 114-113. The court, with 12 judges, has jurisdiction over lower court rulings on patents, trademarks, international trade, and federal claims. The FY2016 budget request was $33.8 million, with the House and Senate committee-reported levels at $33.2 million and $33.8 million respectively. The court also has exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions against the United States and its agencies, with a budget request of $20.2 million and a total provided in P.L. 114-113. The FY2016 funding request for the courts of appeals and district judicial courts was $7,103.0 million, with the House committee-reported level at $7,064.0 million and the Senate committee-reported level at $7,012.9 million. P.L. 114-113 provided $6,929.4 million for salaries, expenses, court security, defender services, and fees of jurors and commissioners. The FY2016 request for this account was $5,459.4 million, with the House committee-reported level at $5,415.0 million and the Senate committee-reported level at $5,377.0 million. The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program funds a federal program to address vaccine tort liability claims. The FY2016 request was $6.0 million, and P.L. 114-113 provides $6.1 million. The account also provides for security needs in courthouses and federal facilities. The FY2016 request for court security was $542.4 million, with the House committee-reported level at $537.0 million and the Senate committee-reported level at $5,377.0 million. The House committee-reported level would have provided $537.0 million and the Senate committee-reported level would have provided $538.8 million. P.L. 114-113 provides $538.2 million for funding the operations of federal public defender and community defender organizations, as well as compensation for defense counsel to indigent individuals. The FY2016 request was $1,057.6 million, with P.L. 114-113 providing $1,004.9 million for fees and allowances for jurors and compensation for jury and land commissioners. The AOUSC FY2016 request was $52.4 million, with P.L. 114-113 providing $44.2 million. The AOUSC supports the judiciary by providing administrative, management, program, and IT services. The Federal Judicial Center conducts research and evaluation for the Judicial Conference committees and courts. The FY2016 request for AOUSC was $87.6 million, with P.L. 114-113 providing $85.7 million. The Federal Judicial Center conducts research and evaluation for the Judicial Conference committees and courts, providing orientation, education, and training. The FY2016 request was $27.7 million, with P.L. 114-113 providing $27.7 million. The commission promulgates sentencing policies for the federal criminal justice system, with a FY2016 request of $17.5 million and P.L. 114-113 providing $17.6 million. Additionally, a mandatory account funds payments to retired judges and families, with a FY2016 request of $132.0 million. The FY2016 request for funding for spouses and dependent children of deceased judicial officers was $132.0 million. P.L. 114-113 provided funding at the requested level in Title VI of the FSGG bill. Provisions in P.L. 114-113 included salaries and expenses for experts, transfers between judiciary appropriations accounts, a limitation on official reception expenses, language for judiciary repairs, continuation of a court security pilot program, and a one-year extension of temporary judgeships in specific districts.
